conclusion: Need to find the acceleration of the particle during the time interval from 1 to 3 seconds using a velocity-time graph.

Graph shows velocity in m/s on the y-axis and time in seconds on the x-axis. Horizontal line at 2 m/s from 0 to 1 second, then a straight line decreasing from 2 m/s at 1 second to -2 m/s at 3 seconds.
Acceleration is the rate of change of velocity with respect to time, given by the slope of the velocity-time graph.
Identify initial and final velocities at 1 and 3 seconds: 2 m/s and -2 m/s respectively. Change in velocity (∆v) is -4 m/s.
Time interval (∆t) is 2 seconds. Acceleration (a) is ∆v/∆t = -4 m/s / 2 s = -2 m/s².
Negative sign indicates acceleration is in the negative direction, consistent with decreasing velocity.
Verify acceleration is constant by noting the line between 1 and 3 seconds is straight.
Units of velocity are m/s and time is s, so acceleration is in m/s².
Consider calculating average acceleration to confirm: change in velocity divided by change in time.
Recalculate using formula a = (v_f - v_i)/t: a = (-2 - 2)/2 = -4/2 = -2 m/s².
Consider other parts of the graph: from 0 to 1 second, velocity is constant, so acceleration is 0 m/s².
After 3 seconds, graph isn't shown, but not relevant to the interval in question.
Physical interpretation: particle decelerates uniformly from 2 m/s to -2 m/s, confirming constant negative acceleration.
Final confirmation that acceleration during the interval is -2 m/s².
